page.title: 06THE HALL AT HARDWICK
page.content: Tens of thousands flock each year to {Hardwick Hall,}which has been owned since 1959 by the{National Trust.}It was built in the late sixteenth century by{"Bess of Hardwick" (Elizabeth Dowager Countess of Shrewsbury). It is a grand and impressive building, still richly {decorated}and splendidly{furnished. One of the Hall's great features is its large proportion of window to wall. The windows increase progressively in height from the ground upwards.This reflects the interior arrangement-servants quarters, then family apartments and then state rooms.This vertical emphasis is further increased by the presence of six towers, on top of which the initials{"E.S."}proudly stand- perhaps erected lest we should forget the lady behind it all!
